questions.text:
The Chorionicity of a Dizygotic pregnancy?

 

  1. Monochorionic Monoamniotic
  2. Monochorionic Diamniotic
  3. Monoamniotic Dichorionic
  4. Dichorionic Diamniotic
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 4.

 

Types of twins:

 

  • Dizygotic twins are formed when 2 ova are fertilized by 2 sperm, so they are always Dichorionic Diamniotic
  • Monozygotic (1 ova + 1 sperm) – undergoes division & Dizygotic (2 ova + 2 sperm)
  • Depending on when they divide, different types of twins are formed
    • First 3 days – Dichorionic Diamniotic
    • 4th day – 7th day – Monochorionic Diamniotic
    • 8th – 12th day – Monochorionic Monoamniotic
    • After 13th day – Conjoined twins (MC – thoracopagus)

 

Let us look at all the options:

 

  1. Monochorionic Monoamniotic: This means there is one chorionic sac and one amniotic sac. This situation is typical for monozygotic twins who split very late after fertilization( day 8-12)
  2. Monochorionic Diamniotic: This indicates one chorionic sac and two amniotic sacs. This also generally occurs in monozygotic twins, where the division happens a bit earlier than in monoamniotic twins. (day4-7)
  3. Monoamniotic Dichorionic: This combination doesn't exist in nature. Monoamniotic means one amniotic sac, and dichorionic would imply two chorionic sacs – these two conditions are mutually exclusive.
  4. Dichorionic Diamniotic (Correct Answer): This means two chorionic sacs and two amniotic sacs. This is the typical scenario for dizygotic twins, where two separate eggs are fertilized by two separate sperm. It could also occur in monozygotic twins when division occurs  before day3.

 

Educational Objective: The chorionicity and amnionicity of a pregnancy are important in understanding the type of twin or multiple pregnancy and in managing it appropriately. Dizygotic (fraternal) twins almost always result in a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

 

Ref: Williams Page 865, 25th edition

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida is diagnosed to have a twin pregnancy on her first trimester ultrasound. The following image is seen on ultrasound. What is the Chorionicity of this twin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monochorionic diamniotic

 

  • Determination of chorionicity:
    • Determined best by ultrasound in the first trimester (8- 10 weeks)
    • Twin peak sign (Lambda sign) – Dichorionic Diamniotic Twins
    • Inverted T sign – Monochorionic Diamniotic
    • No intervening membrane in Monochorionic Monoamniotic Twins

 

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Monochorionic Diamniotic (Likely Answer): One chorionic sac but have two separate amniotic sacs. Key ultrasound features include a thin membrane separating the twins and the 'T-sign' at the point where the membrane meets the placenta.

 

Option B. Monochorionic Monoamniotic: Twins share both the chorionic and amniotic sacs. On ultrasound, there would be no membrane separating the twins. This is rarer and carries higher.

 

Option C. Dichorionic Diamniotic: This is when each twin has its own chorionic and amniotic sac. On ultrasound, this is suggested by the 'lambda (λ) sign' or 'twin peak sign,' where the placenta tissue extends between the membranes.

 

Option D. Conjoined Twins: This is a rare form of monozygotic twinning where the twins are physically connected. It's typically identifiable on ultrasound by the continuous body structure between the twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lambda sign (Twin peak sign): Seen in Dichorionic Diamniotic twins on ultrasound
  • Inverted T/ Reversed T sign: Seen in Monochorionic Diamniotic twins on ultrasound

 

Ref: page no 868-869, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida is diagnosed to have a twin pregnancy on her first trimester ultrasound. The following image is seen on ultrasound. What is chorionicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dichorionic diamniotic

 

  • Determination of chorionicity:
    • Determined best by ultrasound in the 1st trimester (8- 10 weeks)
    • Twin peak sign (Lambda sign) – Dichorionic Diamniotic Twins
    • Inverted T sign – Monochorionic Diamniotic
    • No intervening membrane in Monochorionic Monoamniotic Twins

 

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Monochorionic Diamniotic: This type involves one shared chorion (outer membrane) and two separate amnions (inner membranes) for each twin. On ultrasound, this is indicated by a thin dividing membrane (inverted T sign).

 

Option B. Monochorionic Monoamniotic: Twins share the same chorion and amnion. This is a rare and high-risk situation as it can lead to complications like cord entanglement. On ultrasound, there would be no membrane separating the twins.

 

Option C. Dichorionic Diamniotic (Likely Answer): Each twin has its own chorion and amnion. This is the most common type of twin pregnancy and is considered the lowest risk. On ultrasound, this is indicated by the presence of a 'twin peak' or 'lambda' sign, where a wedge of placental tissue extends between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

 

Option D. Conjoined Twins: This is an extremely rare condition where the twins are physically connected to each other. It is usually identifiable on ultrasound by the continuous body structure shared between the twins.

 

Educational Objective: The chorionicity in twin pregnancies is determined through ultrasound features, with dichorionic diamniotic twins having separate chorionic and amniotic sacs for each twin, often indicated by the presence of the 'twin peak' or 'lambda' sign

 

Ref: page no 868-869, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Examining the placenta post delivery
Number of placentas
Presence and thickness of intertwin membrane on ultrasound
Doppler of the umbilical arteries

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT help in determining the type of twins?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Doppler of the umbilical arteries.

 

Chorionicity and type of twins can be determined by:

 

  1. Ultrasound
    • Sex of the fetuses (if different, the twins are dizygotic; however same sex fetuses can be any type of twin)
    • Number of placentae: two in dizygotic
    • Presence and thickness of the intertwin membrane
  2. Examination of the placenta and membranes after delivery

 

  • Doppler does not help in determining the type of twins

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Examining the Placenta Post Delivery: By examining the placenta(s) and membranes after birth, clinicians can determine whether the twins were monochorionic (sharing one placenta) or dichorionic (each having their own placenta).

 

Option B. Number of Placentas: Observing the number of placentas during pregnancy can suggest the type of twins. Two distinct placentas typically indicate dichorionic twins, whereas a single placenta suggests monochorionic twins.

 

Option C. Presence and Thickness of Intertwin Membrane on Ultrasound: The characteristics of the membrane separating the twins on ultrasound are key for determining chorionicity and amnionicity. A thin membrane often indicates monochorionic diamniotic twins, and a thicker membrane with the 'twin peak' or 'lambda' sign suggests dichorionic diamniotic twins.

 

Option D. Doppler of the Umbilical Arteries (Correct Answer): Doppler studies of the umbilical arteries are important for assessing fetal wellbeing and blood flow, but they do not provide information regarding the chorionicity or amnionicity of the twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorionicity and type of twins can be determined by:

 

1. Ultrasound

  • Sex of the fetuses (if different, the twins are dizygotic; however same sex fetuses can be any type of twin)
  • Number of placentae: two in dizygotic
  • Presence and thickness of the intertwin membrane

2. Examination of the placenta and membranes after delivery

 

Ref: page no 867, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Radiofrequency ablation of the anastomotic vessels
Laser ablation of anastomotic vessels
KCl injection intra-cardiac

questions.text: A 34-year woman was diagnosed to have twin to twin transfusion syndrome at 28 weeks gestation. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laser ablation of anastomotic vessels.

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome is seen in monochorionic pregnancy
  • In this syndrome, there are vascular communications or anastomoses between the twins
  • There is blood flow or transfusion from the donor twin to the recipient twin
  • The donor twin becomes anemic and may suffer FGR and oligohydramnios
  • The recipient twin may develop hydramnios, hypervolemia, HTN, polycythemia and congestive heart failure
  • Treatment of TTTS includes
    • laser ablation of anastomotic vessels (treatment of choice)
    • Radiofrequency ablation of anastomotic vessels
    • Septostomy
    • Amnioreduction

 

Educational Objective: The optimal management of TTTS involves laser ablation of the anastomotic vessels, a procedure that targets the abnormal vascular connections between the twins. This intervention aims to balance the blood flow and amniotic fluid levels, thus improving outcomes for both fetuses.

 

Ref: page no 867, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Elective LSCS at 34 weeks
Elective LSCS at 37 weeks
Induction of labor at 37 weeks
Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

questions.text: A 36-year lady was diagnosed to have monoamniotic monochorionic twins. She is now 33 weeks. What should be the plan of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elective LSCS at 34 weeks

 

Monoamniotic Twin Pregnancy

 

  • Absence of an inter-twin dividing membrane
  • Risk of Cord entanglement as both the twins are in the same amniotic cavity
  • Management: Elective LSCS after 34 weeks after corticosteroids
  • This is done to prevent sudden IUD of one or both twins due to cord entanglement

 

Let's look at each option:

 

Option A. Elective LSCS at 34 weeks (Correct Answer): Monoamniotic monochorionic twins are at high risk for complications such as cord entanglement and compression. Elective Cesarean section (LSCS) around 34 weeks is often recommended to reduce these risks while balancing the complications of prematurity.

 

Option B. Elective LSCS at 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks in a monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancy might increase the risk of intrauterine fetal demise due to cord complications. Earlier delivery is generally preferred.

 

Option C. Induction of Labor at 37   weeks: Induction of labor is typically avoided in monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancies due to the high risk of cord entanglement and compression during vaginal delivery.

 

Option D. Wait for Spontaneous Onset of Labor: Waiting for spontaneous labor is not recommended in monoamniotic monochorionic twins due to the increased risks associated with prolonging the pregnancy, including the potential for cord accidents.

 

Educational Objective: In monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancies, where twins share both the amniotic sac and the placenta, the risks of cord entanglement and compression are significant. To minimize these risks, elective Cesarean section around 34 weeks gestation is often the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: page no 873, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: External podalic version
Internal podalic version

questions.text: Identify the procedure done as shown in the image
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal podalic version

 

  • The maneuver shown in internal podalic version
  • It is indicated in delivery of a second of twin if in transverse line and External cephalic version or external podalic version has failed.
  • It is done under GA
  • Baby is delivered by total breech extraction

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. External Podalic Version: This is a procedure used to turn a fetus from a breech or transverse position into a head-down (cephalic) position by applying pressure on the mother's abdomen. It's done externally and is not indicated for the delivery of a baby.

 

Option B. Kristaller Maneuver: This is supra-pubic pressure applied in delivery of the aftercoming head in breech to maintain flexion and also in shoulder dystocia as this helps in disimpaction of the shoulder

 

Option C. Internal Podalic Version (Correct Answer): This is a procedure used primarily in the delivery of the second twin if it's in a transverse lie and external versions have failed. It involves the obstetrician inserting a hand into the uterus, grasping the fetus' feet, and delivering it by breech extraction. This is typically performed under general anesthesia.

 

Option D. Lovset Maneuver: The Lovset maneuver is a specialized technique used in the vaginal delivery of breech babies, to facilitate the safe delivery of extended arms.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure used in specific circumstances, particularly for the delivery of a second twin in a transverse position when external versions are not successful

 

Ref: page no 890, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Complication specific to monoamniotic twins is
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cord entanglement

 

Cord entanglement occurs in monoamniotic monochorionic twins. Here there is no inter twin membrane and the cord easily entangles causing IUD of 1 or both twins. Hence delivery at 34 weeks in these twins is recommended by elective LSCS

 

The other complications, i.e. TTTS, TRAP and acardiac twins are seen in monochorionic diamniotic twins due to vascular communications.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Acardiac Twins: This refers to a specific type of twin pregnancy complication associated with Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) sequence, which typically occurs in monochorionic pregnancies, not exclusively in monoamniotic twins.

 

Option B. Cord Entanglement (Correct Answer): Cord entanglement is a complication particularly specific to monoamniotic twins. Since both babies are in the same amniotic sac, their umbilical cords can become entangled, which poses a significant risk of cord compression and compromised blood flow to one or both babies.

 

Option C. TRAP (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): TRAP sequence is a complication of monochorionic pregnancies where one twin is acardiac and typically non-viable. While it occurs in monochorionic pregnancies, it is not specific to monoamniotic twins.

 

Option D. TTTS (Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome): TTTS is a condition that affects monochorionic twins, characterized by an imbalance in the blood flow between the twins.

 

Educational Objective: In monoamniotic twin pregnancies, the shared amniotic sac leads to a specific risk of cord entanglement, which requires careful monitoring and often early delivery to prevent fetal distress or demise.

 

Ref: page no 873, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum if the baby’s blood group is Rh positive
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum irrespective of baby blood group.
No need of additional dose since she is ICT negative
Given another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum only if ICT is positive

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother, who has Indirect Coombs (ICT), negative was given Anti-D at 28 weeks pregnancy. Which of the following is the correct option regarding Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum if the baby’s blood group is Rh positive

 

Prophylaxis:

 

  • Anti D (300 mcg IM) given at 28 weeks (If ICT is negative)
  • Repeated within 72 h after delivery if baby is Rh positive
  • 300 mcg neutralizes 30 ml of fetal blood (15 ml of fetal red cells)
  • Avoid past dates; Avoid methylergometrine
  • Delivery is the cause of 90% of feto maternal haemorrhage
  • Also given after inciting events (When feto maternal haemorrhage can happen)
    • Spontaneous/ induced abortion/ MTP/ fetal demise at any gestation
    • Ectopic pregnancy, Molar pregnancy
    • Selective fetal reduction/ Amniocentesis/ Chorionic villous sampling
    • External cephalic version
    • Manual removal of placenta
    • Abruptio Placentae/ Abdominal trauma

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum if the baby’s blood group is Rh positive (Correct Answer): If an Rh-negative mother delivers an Rh-positive baby, she is at risk of being sensitized to Rh-positive blood. Administering Anti-D within 72 hours postpartum can prevent Rh immunization in future pregnancies.

 

Option B. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum irrespective of baby blood group: incorrect. The need for a postpartum dose of Anti-D depends on the baby's Rh status. If the baby is Rh-negative, the mother's body will not be exposed to Rh-positive antigens, and thus she would not require another dose.

 

Option C. No need for an additional dose since she is ICT negative: incorrect. Being ICT  negative before delivery means the mother has not yet formed antibodies against Rh-positive blood. However, this does not preclude the need for postpartum prophylaxis if the baby is Rh-positive.

 

Option D. Given another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum only if ICT is positive: This statement is incorrect. Anti-D is given postpartum to prevent the mother from developing antibodies, not because she has already developed them. An ICT positive result would indicate that the mother has already been sensitized, which is what the prophylaxis aims to prevent.

 

Educational Objective: The administration of Anti-D prophylaxis to an Rh-negative mother is critical for preventing Rh immunization. If the newborn is Rh-positive, the mother should receive another dose of Anti-D within 72 hours postpartum, irrespective of her ICT status at the time of delivery. This strategy is essential for safeguarding maternal health in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 25-year G2A1 at 28 weeks with blood group B negative gets an ICT done. The report is 1:32. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV

 

Management of an already sensitized pregnancy (i.e., ICT positive)

 

  • Check ICT monthly till 24 weeks and weekly thereafter till critical titers are reached
  • In ICT, higher titres indicate greater antibody concentration.
  • Critical titre 1:32 > 1:16
  • Once critical titre is reached - Check Peak systolic velocity of Middle cerebral artery (PSV of MCA)
  • If PSV of MCA > 1.5 MoM Cordocentesis and check fetal Hematocrit (Hct)
  • If Hct of fetal blood is < 30% - Intra uterine transfusion with O negative blood is transfused

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Repeat ICT after 2 weeks: While repeating the ICT could provide additional information on whether the antibody levels are increasing, it would not give immediate insight into the fetal condition at the time.

 

Option B. Give steroid cover and deliver: Administering steroids and delivering the baby is a course of action for cases where there's evidence of fetal distress or significant maturity, and the pregnancy is at a viable stage. At 28 weeks, unless there's urgent evidence of fetal compromise, immediate delivery is not typically the first step.

 

Option C. Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV (Correct Answer): Performing an ultrasound to assess the fetus, including the Middle Cerebral Artery Peak Systolic Velocity (MCA-PSV), helps determine if the fetus is anemic. An elevated MCA-PSV is indicative of fetal anemia and may necessitate further interventions. This is a non-invasive way to monitor the fetus and is the next best step in this case.

 

Option D. Perform intrauterine transfusion: This is a treatment for fetal anemia, not a diagnostic step. It would be considered if there's evidence of significant fetal anemia and distress, typically indicated by an abnormal MCA-PSV and other ultrasound findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pregnant Rh-negative woman with a positive ICT, the next best step is to perform an ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV to check for fetal anemia. This approach allows for timely and non-invasive monitoring of the fetus, which is crucial for deciding on further management to prevent fetal morbidity and mortality.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Anti – D prophylaxis should be given following delivery.
Anti -D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible only if she has not received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.
Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.
Anti-D prophylaxis is not required.

questions.text: A 34-year primigravida presents at 34 weeks with mild spotting. She is not in labor and the ultrasound shows the placenta in the upper segment. On evaluation, her blood group is B -negative and her husband is Rh positive. What is true regarding Anti – D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

(Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

 

  • Prophylaxis:
    • Anti D (300 mcg IM) given at 28 weeks (If ICT is negative)
    • Repeated within 72 h after delivery if baby is Rh positive
    • 300 mcg neutralizes 30 ml of fetal blood (15 ml of fetal red cells)
    • Avoid past dates; Avoid methylergometrine
    • Delivery is the cause of 90% of feto maternal haemorrhage
    • Also given after inciting events (When feto maternal haemorrhage can happen)
    • Dose: 50 mcg < 12 weeks and 300 mcg if > 12 weeks

 

Inciting events:

 

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given following delivery: While it's true that Anti-D is routinely given postpartum, this option overlooks the immediate need due to the current bleeding episode.

 

Option B. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible only if she has not received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks: This option is not accurate because the need for Anti-D prophylaxis in the event of antepartum bleeding is independent of whether she received prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

Option C. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks (Correct Answer): This is the correct approach. The woman should receive Anti-D prophylaxis as soon as possible following the bleeding episode, regardless of her having received a routine dose at 28 weeks. Each episode of potential fetal-maternal hemorrhage, such as bleeding in pregnancy, warrants a dose of Anti-D.

 

Option D. Anti-D prophylaxis is not required: This is incorrect. Given the woman’s Rh-negative status and the occurrence of antepartum bleeding, Anti-D prophylaxis is necessary.

 

Educational Objective: Rh-negative pregnant women should receive Anti-D prophylaxis following any antepartum bleeding event to prevent Rh sensitization, regardless of prior prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

choices.text: Arrange for cordocentesis and consider Intra uterine transfusion if PCV < 30%
Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver.
Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry
Repeat a PSV of the MCA after  2 weeks

questions.text: A 25-year G3P2 presented to the Antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. Her blood group is B neg and her partners blood group is B +. Indirect Coombs test revealed high titers and an MCA revealed an increased diastolic flow > 1.5 MoM with a normal peak systolic velocity. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Repeat a PSV of the MCA after 2 weeks

 

  • In the scenario given, it is mentioned that the peak systolic velocity (PSV) is normal.
  • The patient needs to be followed up.
  • Only when the PSV> 1.5 MoM; should a cordocentesis be done

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Arrange for cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if PCV < 30%: Cordocentesis is a procedure to obtain fetal blood and assess hematocrit (PCV). Intrauterine transfusion is considered if fetal anemia is confirmed. However, this step might be premature if only the diastolic flow in the MCA is increased, and the peak systolic velocity (PSV) is normal. Cordocentesis carries risks and is typically considered when there's clear evidence of fetal anemia.

 

Option B. Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver: Administering Betamethasone and planning for delivery would be considered if there's evidence of significant fetal compromise and the pregnancy is at a stage where delivery is viable. At 28 weeks, unless there is urgent evidence of severe fetal distress, immediate delivery is not typically the first choice.

 

Option C. Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry: Amniotic fluid spectrophotometry is used to measure bilirubin levels, which can indicate fetal hemolysis. However, with the advent of non-invasive methods like MCA Doppler, its use has decreased

 

Option D. Repeat a PSV of the MCA after 2 weeks (Correct Answer): Since the peak systolic velocity of the MCA is normal, indicating no immediate severe fetal anemia, monitoring with a repeat MCA Doppler in 2 weeks is a prudent approach.

 

Educational Objective: In cases of suspected fetal anemia due to Rh incompatibility, monitoring with repeated MCA Doppler studies is crucial, especially when initial findings are borderline or inconclusive. This approach allows for close surveillance of the fetus and helps in deciding the appropriate time for interventions like cordocentesis or intrauterine transfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal growth restriction
Fibroid uterus
Intrauterine fetal demise

questions.text: A 25y G2 presents at 30 weeks. On examination, the uterine height is 28 weeks and the symphysio-fundal height is 27 cm. All are possible causes except:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Fibroid uterus

  • A fibroid uterus will make the uterus appear more than the period of gestation
  • In all the other choices, the uterine height will be less than the POG

Educational Objective: 

Causes for the uterine height < Period of gestation are

  1. Wrong dates
  2. Fetal growth restriction
  3. Oligohydramnios
  4. Fetal demise
  5. Transverse lie

Causes for the uterine height > Period of gestation are

  1. Wrong dates
  2. Full bladder
  3. Macrosomia
  4. Twin pregnancy
  5. Fibroid uterus
  6. Polyhydramnios
  7. Molar pregnancy
  8. Concealed abruption

Ref: Page no 850, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Emergency LSCS
Induction of labor
Repeat Doppler after 1 week

questions.text: A 30y G2 with a previous LSCS presents at 35 weeks pregnancy with fetal growth restriction. An umbilical artery doppler reveals the following:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Repeat Doppler after 1 week

  • The image shows a normal umbilical artery doppler.
  • Management in such a patient would be to repeat weekly dopplers and deliver her at 37 weeks of gestation.
  • In case there is absent or reversal of diastolic flow on the umbilical artery doppler, earlier delivery is indicated

Educational Objective:

Management of Fetal Growth Restriction

 

 

Ref: Page no 854, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Increased S/D ratio – Absent end diastolic flow – Reversal of end diastolic flow
Absent end diastolic flow - Increased S/D ratio – Reversal of end diastolic flow
Reversal of end diastolic flow - increased S/D ratio – Absent end diastolic flow
Increased S/D ratio – Reversal of end diastolic flow – Absent end diastolic flow

questions.text: Correct sequence of umbilical artery doppler findings indicative of progressive worsening intrauterine fetal hypoxia is?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Increased S/D ratio – Absent end diastolic flow – Reversal of end diastolic flow

The order of changes in the umbilical artery in Doppler in FGR are:

  • Increased S/D ratio (Reduced diastolic flow) – Absent end diastolic flow – Reversal of end diastolic flow

Educational Objective: 

Umbilical Artery: Changes in Doppler in Fetal Growth Restriction

  • Initially: Decreased end diastolic velocity: Increased Pulsatility Index (PI) and increasing S/D Ratio
  • Later: Absent end diastolic flow
  • Last: Reversal of end diastolic flow

 

Ref: Page no 854, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Very preterm is defined as preterm birth at:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 28- 32weeks

Educational Obective: 

Preterm is defined as period of gestation between 24w – 36w (+6d)

  • Extremely preterm is 24 – 28w
  • Very preterm is 28 – 32 w
  • Moderate preterm is 32 – 34 w
  • Late preterm is 34w – 36w (+6d)

 

 

Ref: Page no: 804, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Transvaginal scan at 12 weeks
Trans abdominal scan at 12 weeks
Transvaginal scan at 16 weeks
Transabdominal scan at 16 weeks

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L0 presents to the OPD at 8 weeks. She has a history of a previous preterm delivery at 32 weeks. A cervical length measurement is advised. Which of these statements regarding cervical length measurement is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Transvaginal scan at 16 week  

Let's Discuss all the Options: 

  • Option A: Transvaginal scan at 12 weeks: Although the cervical length can be measured during the Level 1 scan (11-14 weeks), a better predictor is a short cervix (< 2.5 cm) between 16-24 weeks
  • Option B: Transabdominal scan at 12 weeks: A transvaginal scan is preferred for cervical length measurement
  • Option C: Transvaginal scan at 16 weeks is correct as an ultrasound measurement done between 16-24 weeks is a predictor of preterm labor. A cervical length < 2.5 cm (between 16-24 weeks) is a predictor for preterm labor
  • Option D: Transabdominal scan at 16 weeks: Although 16 weeks is a good time to check the cervical length on ultraosund, it is better visualized and measured by a trans vaginal scan. 

Educational Objective:

  • Cervical length measurement is a predictor of preterm birth. 
  • Cervical length is measured by a Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) at 16 – 24 weeks
  • Cervical length < 25 mm is a predictor for preterm birth

 

Ref: Page no: 815, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal distress

questions.text: A 30-year G2P1L1 presents at 31 weeks to the labor room with c/o leaking and mild abdominal pain. All the below are absolute contra-indications to tocolysis except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. oligohydramnios

Oligohydrmanios is NOT a c/i to tocolysis

Absolute contra-indications to tocolysis include the following:

  1.  
  • Active labor
  • Fetal distress
  • Fetal death
  • Eclampsia
  • Anomalies not compatible to life
  • Abruptio placentae
  • Pregnancy > 34 weeks
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Antepartum hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

Absolute contra-indications to tocolysis include the following:

  1.  
  • Active labor
  • Fetal distress
  • Fetal death
  • Eclampsia
  • Anomalies not compatible to life

  • Antepartum hemorrhage

(Ref: Page no: 821, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

questions.text: A 24 yr primi presents at 33 weeks with abdominal pain. One examination the os is 2 cm dilated and early effaced. She has no additional risk factor, and her BP is 110/ 70 mmHg. Tocolytics and corticosteroids are administered. The drug of choice for tocolysis in preterm labor is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nifedipine

 

The first line for tocolysis is CCBs and the most commonly used tocolytic is nifedipine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ritodrine: This is a beta 2 agonist and is is not a preferred tocolytic due to its high side effect profile which includes hypotension, tachycardia, pulmonary edema and hyperglycemia

 

Option C. Indomethacin: This is also not preferred especially if > 32 weeks as it can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 

Option D. Atosiban: Although this drug has an excellent side effect profile, it is not usually used as a 1st line drug due to its cost. It acts as an oxytocin receptor antagonist

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium channel blockers are the tocolytci agent of choice if no contra-indication

 

Ref: Page no 824, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Abruptio placentae
Preterm labor

questions.text: A 24 y G2P1 presents to the labor room at 32 weeks with complaints of abdominal pain and backache. Her BP is 120/80 mmHg. The uterus is 32 weeks size and there is occasional hardening at the fundus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Preterm labor

The most likely diagnosis is preterm labor based on symptoms and signs i.e 32 weeks gestation with abdominal pain, backache and hardening of the uterus.

Other Options

  • Option A: Abruption is unlikely as there is no bleeding. The uterus corresponds to the POG and there is no tenderness. However to diagnose preterm labor, cervical dilatation and effacement should also be present
  • Option B: There is no h/o urinary symptoms mentioned and this rule out UTI
  • Option D: There is no h/o vaginal leaking given and this rules our Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes

Educational Objective: 

  • Preterm labor is defined (by WHO) as the onset of regular uterine contractions (before 37 weeks) i.e. at least 4 contractions in 20 minutes assocuated with cervical dilatation of > 1 cm or effacement > 80%

 

Ref: Page no: 814, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 28 – 32 weeks
32 – 34 weeks
24 – 30 weeks
24 – 28 weeks

questions.text: Extremely preterm is defined as preterm birth at:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 24-28 weeks.

Educational Obective: 

Preterm is defined as period of gestation between 24w – 36w (+6d)

  • Extremely preterm is 24 – 28w
  • Very preterm is 28 – 32 w
  • Moderate preterm is 32 – 34 w
  • Late preterm is 34w – 36w (+6d)

 

 

Ref: Page no: 804, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Foul smelling discharge

questions.text: All are signs of chorioamnionitis except:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Fetal bradycardia

Fetal tachycardia is a sign of chorioamnionitis (not bradycardia)

Educational Objective: 

Chorioamnionitis:

    • Chorioamnionitis is intra-amniotic infection and inflammation
    • Maternal temp > 390C – ESSENTIAL (only definitive sign of chorioamnionitis)
    • Other features:
      • Maternal tachycardia
      • Fetal tachycardia
      • Maternal leukocytosis
      • Uterine tenderness
      • Foul smelling discharge
      • Raised TLC
      • Raised CRP
      • HVS culture positive

 

Ref: Page no: 821, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 28 y G2P1 presents to the OPD with a missed period and history of mild spotting PV. A urine pregnancy test done at home shows 2 lines. All are possible diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Complete Abortion

 

  • Complete Abortion will present with heavy bleeding with the passage of fleshy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Placental sign or implantation bleeding will have minimal bleeding
  • Threatened and missed abortion will only have spotting or minimal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Spontaneous Abortion

 

 

Ref: Page No: 159 DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

questions.text: A 24-y woman presents to the emergency with a history of amenorrhea for 2.5 months. She complains of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding since a day. On examination her PR and BP are normal. Abdominal examination reveals mild tenderness. On speculum examination, there is bleeding from the cervical os. Bimanual examination reveals a 10 weeks uterus and the cervix admits 1 finger. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inevitable abortion

 

  • In the given scenario, there is no passage of fleshy mass; the cervical os is open and the uterus corresponds to the POG – this points to inevitable abortion as seen in the table below.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Missed abortion: In missed abortion, the os will be closed and the patient is usually asymptomatic or has mild spotting
  • Option B: Incomplete abortion: In this the uterine height will be smaller than the POG. Here the uterine height = POG.
  • Option D: Fibroid polyp characteristically presents as intermenstrual bleeding. There will not be any amenorrhea usually. Fibroid polyp can also present as a mass PV.

 

Thus option C; inevitable abortion is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 351, William’s 25th edition

choices.text: Blood clots in the endometrial cavity
Heteroechoic contents seen in the uterine cavity
Normal endometrial lining
The gestational sac seen low down in the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 25y old P2L2 presents with history suggestive of a complete abortion. What would be the expected finding on doing an ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Normal endometrial lining

 

In a complete abortion, the ultrasound will be normal, i.e. nothing will be seen inside the endometrial cavity

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ultrasound findings in different abortions are as given below:

Inevitable abortion

questions.text: A 23 y P2L2 comes to the OPD. She says that she missed her period by 10 days and is now complaining of spotting. There is also mild abdominal pain. On examination the uterus is 6 weeks size and the os is closed. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Threatened abortion

 

  • There is no passage of fleshy mass which rules out complete abortion and incomplete abortion.
  • The os is closed and hence the answer is threatened abortion and not inevitable abortion in which the os will be open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 349, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida comes to the OPD. She is 5 weeks pregnant and complains of spotting PV. She is not willing for a vaginal examination. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Threatened abortion

 

  • At 5 weeks pregnancy, a TVS should show an intrauterine gestational sac which is seen in the image hence this is a threatened abortion

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: In a complete abortion, the uterine cavity will be empty
  • Option B: In an ectopic pregnancy, a pseudo sac or an empty intra-uterine cavity may be seen
  • Option C: In an incomplete abortion, retained products of conception will be seen

 

Educational Objective:

 

A yolk sac appears within the g. sac at 5.5 weeks

 

An embryo with cardiac activity within the g. sac at 6 weeks.

 

An Ectopic pregnancy will present on TVS as

 

  • No evidence of intrauterine pregnancy
  • Sometimes a pseudo sac is seen intra-uterine
  • Adnexal mass seen
    • G sac with or without yolk sac/ embryo
    • Heterogenous mass in the adnexa (blob sign)
    • Ring like structure in the adnexa (Bagel sign)

 

 

 

Ref: Page no. 159, William’s 25th edition

choices.text: 10 mm
15 mm
20 mm
25 mm

questions.text: An anembryonic pregnancy is described on transvaginal scan when the embryo is absent at a mean sac diameter of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 25 mm

 

  • Anembryonic pregnancy is diagnosed on TVS when the mean sac diameter (MSD) is 25 mm and there is no embryo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anembryonic pregnancy is diagnosed on TVS when the mean sac diameter (MSD) is 25 mm and there is no embryo.

 

Ref: Page no 352; William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 26y old gives a history of two 1st trimester abortions following delivery of a preterm baby at 30 weeks due to severe preeclampsia. She is anxious and wants to be evaluated preconceptionally. Which of the following investigation will you advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lupus anticoagulant

 

Based on the history, Antiphospholipid antibody Syndrome is probable. Hence the investigation of choice is Lupus Anticoagulant.

 

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome

 

  • Commonly presents as RPL
  • Diagnosed based on Sapporo’s Criteria which has Lab and Clinical criteria -At least one clinical and 1 lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

 

Clinical Criteria

 

Obstetric

 

  • One or more unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus > 10 weeks

 

OR

 

  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

 

OR

 

  • 3 or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks

 

Vascular

 

  • 1 or more episode of arterial/venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

 

Lab Criteria (Present on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart)

 

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant

 

OR

 

  • Medium to high titers of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin Antibodies

 

OR

 

  • Anti β2 glycoprotein – IgG or IgM Antibody

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome

 

  • Commonly presents as RPL
  • Diagnosed based on Sapporo’s Criteria which has Lab and Clinical criteria -At least one clinical and 1 lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

 

Clinical Criteria

 

Obstetric

 

  • One or more unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus > 10 weeks

 

OR

 

  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

 

OR

 

  • 3 or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks

 

Vascular

 

  • 1 or more episode of arterial/venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

 

Lab Criteria (Present on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart)

 

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant

 

OR

 

  • Medium to high titers of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin Antibodies

 

OR

 

  • Anti β2 glycoprotein – IgG or IgM Antibody

 

Ref: Page no 353, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
Luteal phase defect
Parental chromosomal abnormalities

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 presents to the OPD with a history of recurrent, painless abortions, each occurring in the mid trimester. The most probably cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical insufficiency

 

Cervical Insufficiency

 

  • Typically presents as recurrent painless 2nd trimester loss

 

Other Options:

 

  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome: This typically presents as pregnancy losses which can be any trimester but there is usually a history of 1st trimester losses or a loss in the 3rd trimester due to severe preeclampsia or abruption
  • Luteal phase defect: This usually presents as recurrent 1st trimester abortions
  • Parental chromosomal abnormalities: This is a very rare cause of recurrent 1st trimester abortions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical insufficiency typically presents as recurrent painless 2nd trimester abortions

 

  • Etiology
  • Congenital
    • Inherited weakness of cervix
    • Associated with uterine anomalies/ DES exposure
  • Acquired: Previous cervical trauma:
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Conization of cervix
    • Cervical amputation (part of Fothergill surgery)
    • Trachelectomy
    • Cervical tears during a previous delivery.

 

Ref: Page 354, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: History of 3 or more recurrent, painless 2nd trimester abortions
Cervical length < 25 mm at 14 weeks with a history of an earlier preterm birth
Painless dilated cervix on examination before 24 weeks
Previous history of a preterm birth at 32 weeks

questions.text: All are indications for doing a cervical cerclage except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Previous history of a preterm birth at 32 weeks

 

A previous h/o a preterm birth without a short cervix in the current pregnancy is an indication for starting her on progesterone and no a direct indication for a cerclage

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indications for Cervical Cerclage

 

 

  • History Indicated means: 3 or more previous 2nd trimester/ preterm births
  • USG indicated means
    • H/o 1 or more preterm/ mid-trimester birth with USG cervical length < 25 mm

 

(Not recommended only for short cervical length with no h/o preterm/ mid-trimester birth; Also, not recommended for only funneling seen with no shortening of cervical length)

 

  • Examination indicated means painless mid-trimester cervical dilatation.

  

Ref: Page no 354, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Antiphospholipid Antibody syndrome
Diabetes in pregnancy
Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

questions.text: Sapporo’s Criteria is used to diagnose:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Antiphospholipid Antibody syndrome

 

Sapporo criteria is used to diagnose APLA syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 353, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents with 3 first trimester abortions. Prior to this, she gives a history of a dilatation and curettage several years earlier and also complains of hypomenorrhea. She has come for pre-conceptional counselling. What would be the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopy

 

  • The most likely diagnosis in this patient (h/o RPL, hypomenorrhea with a history of curettage) is Asherman syndrome.
  • Uterine synechiae (Asherman syndrome) usually results from destruction of large areas of endometrium
  • This usually follows curettage.
  • Asherman syndrome can be diagnosed on HSG or saline infusion salpingography (multiple filling defects) or hysteroscopy. Treatment is hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Thus, the most appropriate investigation for this patient is a hysteroscopy.

 

Other Options

 

  • Transvaginal ultrasound: In Asherman syndrome, a TVS will not give much information and is not the investigation of choice
  • TSH: Thyroid disorders can present with RPL and AUB but the classical history of hypomenorrhea following a h/o D & C favors a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome
  • Lupus anticoagulant: This usually presents as RPL or a h/o thrombosis. Hypomenorrhea does not fit into this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine synechiae (Asherman syndrome) usually results from destruction of large areas of endometrium
  • This usually follows curettage.
  • Asherman syndrome can be diagnosed on HSG or saline infusion salpingography (multiple filling defects) or hysteroscopy. Treatment is hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Aspirin and low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with recurrent abortion is diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What will be the treatment during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aspirin and low molecular weight heparin

 

Explanation:

 

Reason for pregnancy loss in APLA is mainly by inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation leading to placental dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Management of APLA
    • Low dose aspirin as soon as pregnancy is confirmed
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) once cardiac activity appears

 

Ref: Page no 355, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 23-year G2 with a previous LSCS presents at 30 weeks with vaginal bleeding. On examination, her PR is 80/ min, and her BP is 120/80 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus which is relaxed, non-tender and the FHR is 130 bpm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transabdominal ultrasound

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical scenario presented is one of antepartum haemorrhage
  • Points in favor of placenta previa
    • No pain
    • h/o prev LSCS
    • vital signs normal
    • Uterus relaxed
    • FHR normal
  • Placenta previa is confirmed by a transabdominal ultrasound

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: A biophysical profile is a combination of an ultrasound and a non-stress test to assess fetal well-being. It's typically used in cases where there is a concern about fetal health, especially in situations like fetal growth restriction or decreased fetal movements. In this case, the fetus seems to be doing well based on the FHR

 

Option B. Corticosteroids: Administering corticosteroids is recommended for fetal lung maturity in cases of preterm labor or when early delivery is anticipated. However,  it doesn't address the immediate need to evaluate the cause of the bleeding.

 

Option C. Emergency LSCS: An emergency lower segment cesarean section might be considered in cases of acute fetal distress or life-threatening maternal conditions. However, given the stable vital signs of both the mother and the fetus, this does not appear to be the immediate requirement.

 

Option D. Transabdominal Ultrasound: This is the most appropriate next step. A transabdominal ultrasound will help assess the placental position, amniotic fluid volume, fetal growth, and activity. It's crucial in this case to rule out placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or vasa previa, which could be causing the bleeding. Additionally, the ultrasound can help clarify why the uterus is measuring larger than expected for the gestational age.

 

Given the information provided, the next best step in management is D. Transabdominal ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant patient with a history of cesarean delivery presenting with vaginal bleeding and a stable condition, the initial step should be to perform a transabdominal ultrasound to assess the placenta, fetus, and amniotic fluid, and to investigate the cause of bleeding

 

Ref: Page no 776, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 35-year G2 with placenta previa presents at 32 weeks with an episode of bleeding. On examination, her vital signs are stable and abdominal exam reveals a relaxed uterus. Expectant management (McAfee Johnson) is initiated. This includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weekly NST

 

Explanation:

 

Components of Expectant Management (MacAfee & Johnson)

 

  • Bed rest
  • Hb and Blood group
  • Hematinics/ Blood transfusion
  • Avoid tocolysis
  • Inj Anti-D for Rh negative women
  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity (< 34 weeks): Inj Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart

 

Let's examine each option:

 

Option A. Bed Rest: This is to reduce physical activity and minimize the risk of triggering further bleeding. It is a standard component of expectant management in such cases.

 

Option B. Corticosteroids: The purpose is to accelerate fetal lung maturity in case an early delivery becomes necessary, which is a significant concern in pregnancies complicated by placenta previa.

 

Option C. Hematinics: Hematinics, such as iron supplements, are often given to pregnant women with placenta previa, especially if they have experienced bleeding. They help in maintaining or improving the hemoglobin levels, which can be critical if the patient loses blood.

 

Option D. Weekly NST (Non-Stress Test): While fetal monitoring is important in the management of high-risk pregnancies, including those with placenta previa, weekly NSTs are not a standard component of the McAfee Johnson protocol for expectant management of placenta previa. NSTs are used to monitor the fetal heart rate and look for signs of fetal distress. However, their frequency and use would be determined based on individual clinical scenarios and may not necessarily be conducted on a weekly basis as a standard protocol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of Expectant Management (MacAfee & Johnson): Done in patients with placenta previa < 37 weeks where there is no active bleeding and maternal and fetal condition is stable:

 

  • Bed rest
  • Hb and Blood group
  • Hematinics/ Blood transfusion
  • Avoid tocolysis
  • Inj Anti-D for Rh negative women
  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity (< 34 weeks): Inj Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart

 

Ref: Page no 776, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
Utero placental insufficiency

questions.text: A 25-year primi with preeclampsia and fetal distress underwent an emergency LSCS. Following delivery of the baby, this was the appearance of the uterus. What could have been the reason for fetal distress?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio Placenta 

 

Explanation:

 

This is Couvelaire uterus. It is seen following concealed abruption and is the appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section. Points about Couvelaire uterus:

 

  • Also called as uteroplacental apoplexy
  • Seen in severe concealed abruption
  • Occurs due to intravasation of blood into uterine musculature
  • The uterus appears dark bluish like a bruise
  • The blood may also seep into the leaves of the broad ligament, in the ovaries or in the peritoneal cavity.
  • It is not an indication for a hysterectomy.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option B. Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD): CPD occurs when the baby's head is too large or the mother's pelvic opening is too small for vaginal delivery. While CPD can cause labor complications and potentially lead to fetal distress, it would not typically result in noticeable changes to the appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section.

 

Option C. Meconium-Stained Amniotic Fluid: Meconium-stained amniotic fluid occurs when the baby passes meconium (early feces) into the amniotic fluid before or during labor. This can be a sign of fetal distress, but it is not directly related to the appearance of the uterus after delivery.

 

Option D. Utero-Placental Insufficiency: This condition occurs when the placenta is not able to provide adequate nutrients and oxygen to the fetus, leading to fetal distress. However, utero-placental insufficiency is a chronic condition and may not directly correlate with the physical appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section.

 

Educational Objective: In the context of emergency cesarean delivery with noted changes in the appearance of the uterus (Couvelaire uterus), abruptio placenta is a likely cause of fetal distress, as it directly impacts the placenta's ability to provide oxygen and nutrients to the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 753, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 21-year primigravida at 36 weeks with chronic hypertension presents with vaginal bleeding with abdominal pain. On examination, her BP is 140/100. The uterus is tense and contracting. The Fetal heart rate is not auscultated. PV examination reveals the cervix is 5 cm dilated and well effaced. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Augment labor

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a patient with abruption with fetal demise
  • Management of Abruption:
    • Blood and blood products to be transfused
    • Immediate Delivery is the rule
    • If fetal distress/maternal shock expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor)
    • If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM Oxytocin)
  • This patient is in labor and fetal demise has occurred. The best management would be to augment labor (ARM + Oxytocin)

   

Let us explore each option:

 

Option A. Augment Labor: Given the signs suggestive of placental abruption and the indication of fetal demise augmenting labor is appropriate if the patient is already in labor.It  can be done with artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and oxytocin to facilitate vaginal delivery, which is generally preferable in the case of fetal demise.

 

Option B. Emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While emergency cesarean section is a critical intervention in cases of placental abruption with a viable fetus and maternal or fetal distress, it may not be the most appropriate choice in the event of confirmed fetal demise, especially if the patient is already in advanced labor.

 

Option C. Tocolysis: Tocolysis, the would be contraindicated in this scenario. There is a need for delivery, not delaying it, especially considering the signs of abruption and fetal demise.

 

Option D. Urgent Ultrasound: While an ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis and assess the situation, the clinical signs (absence of fetal heart rate, vaginal bleeding, and uterine contractions) strongly suggest placental abruption with fetal demise. In this case, the immediate priority is the management of the mother's condition and the delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of Abruption:

 

  • Blood and blood products to be transfused
  • Immediate Delivery is the rule
  • If fetal distress/maternal shock expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor)
  • If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM Oxytocin)

 

Ref: Page no 753, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Red degeneration of fibroid

questions.text: A 35-year Primigravida presents at 30 weeks with abdominal pain for 2 hours. Her BP is 160/100 mmHg. On examination there is pallor. The uterus corresponds to 36 weeks and is tender. The most probable diagnosis is.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruption

 

Explanation:

 

  • Points in favor of abruption
    • Abdominal pain
    • Pallor
    • High BP 
    • Uterine height > POG
  • In all the other choices, the uterine height > POG but pallor and high BP favors the diagnosis of abruption (concealed type).

 

Let us look at the other option:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios refers to an excessive amount of amniotic fluid. While it can cause the uterus to measure larger than the gestational age, it typically does not present with severe abdominal pain and high blood pressure or pallor.

 

Option C. Multiple Pregnancy: A multiple pregnancy (e.g., twins or triplets) can cause the uterus to measure larger than the gestational age. However, it is less likely to present with severe abdominal pain, high blood pressure, and pallor without other accompanying complications.

 

Option D. Red Degeneration of Fibroid: This refers to the degeneration of a uterine fibroid, which can cause acute abdominal pain and a tender uterus. While it could be a consideration, the presence of high blood pressure and the specific pattern of symptoms make placental abruption a more likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman presenting with severe abdominal pain, high blood pressure, a tender uterus that measures larger than the gestational age, and pallor, placental abruption is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Ref: page no 771, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Risk factors for placenta previa include increasing maternal age and multiparity
Conservative management is indicated if the woman is < 37 weeks and hemodynamically stable
Adherent placenta is best diagnosed with an MRI
A transvaginal ultrasound can be safely done to diagnose placenta previa

questions.text: A 30-year G2 with a previous LSCS at 30 weeks with painless vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals a placenta covering the os.  All are true except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adherent placenta is best diagnosed with an MRI

 

Explanation:

 

  • The situation described is of placenta previa 
  • Adherent placenta is best diagnosed by USG and Doppler. MRI is reserved for doubtful cases like in posterior placenta
  • TVS is safe in diagnosing placenta previa
  • Conservative treatment is indicated in a patient less than 37 weeks who is otherwise stable
  • High parity and increasing maternal age are risk factors for placenta previa

 

Let us look at  each statement:

 

Option A. Risk Factors for Placenta Previa Include Increasing Maternal Age and Multiparity: True. These factors can increase the likelihood of abnormal placental implantation.

 

Option B. Conservative Management is Indicated if the Woman is < 37 Weeks and Hemodynamically Stable: True. This approach usually involves close monitoring and delaying delivery until a safer gestational age, as long as both the mother and fetus remain stable.

 

Option C. Adherent Placenta is Best Diagnosed with an MRI: This statement is not entirely accurate. While MRI can be used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta (a condition where the placenta abnormally adheres to the uterine wall), ultrasound, particularly color Doppler ultrasound, is often the first-line imaging modality. MRI may be used as a supplementary tool in complex cases or when ultrasound results are inconclusive.

 

Option D.  A Transvaginal Ultrasound Can Be Safely Done to Diagnose Placenta Previa: True. It provides a clear view of the lower segment of the uterus, helping to determine the placenta's location relative to the cervical os.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adherent placenta is best diagnosed by USG and Doppler. MRI is reserved for doubtful cases like in posterior placenta

 

Ref: Page no 780, 773, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 350 nm
400 nm
450 nm
500 nm

questions.text: On amniotic fluid spectrophotometry, optical density of bilirubin peaks at a wavelength of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 450 nm

 

  • On spectrophotometry, bilirubin levels peak at an optical density wavelength of 450 nm

 

Bilirubin in amniotic fluid has a peak absorption at around 450 nm, which is in the blue region of the visible spectrum. This characteristic peak is used in spectrophotometry to assess the level of bilirubin and, by extension, the degree of fetal hemolysis. Thus option A) is correct.

 

Educational Objective: In amniotic fluid spectrophotometry, bilirubin, an indicator of fetal hemolysis, peaks at an optical density of 450 nm. This knowledge is essential in assessing the severity of fetal hemolytic disease, such as in cases of Rh incompatibility, and guides subsequent management decisions.

 

Ref: Page no 304, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: In asymmetrical IUGR, which of the following is last to be affected:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Brain

  • Asymmetrical IUGR is late in onset i.e. usually occurs in the 3rd trimester
  • It is usually due to utero-placental insufficiency
  • The brain is the last organ to be affected in IUGR

Educational Objective:

The brain is the last organ to be affected in IUGR

 

Ref: Page no 854, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2

 

Correct matching is.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Subcostal vessels and nerve run along the inferior border of the 12th rib. They are not directly associated with any of the specific diaphragmatic openings but are related to the area just below the ribcage They pass behind the lateral arcuate ligament.
  2. The sympathetic trunk runs vertically along the vertebral column. It is located posteriorly in the abdomen and is not directly associated with the diaphragmatic openings but lies behind the medial arcuate ligament.
  3. Superior epigastric vessels are continuations of the internal thoracic (mammary) artery and vein. They travel through the space of Larrey, which is a gap between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm on either side.
  4. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic duct of the body. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm at the level of T12.
  5. The phrenic nerve provides the main motor supply to the diaphragm. The right phrenic nerve enters the thoracic cavity and passes through the caval opening (IVC opening) in the diaphragm at the level of T8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minor openings in Diaphragm:

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 180

choices.text: Associated cardiac anomalies
Double bubble sign

questions.text: A 20-year primigravida is diagnosed to have duodenal atresia on her routine level 2 scan done at 20 weeks. Which of the following would NOT have been seen on the ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macrosomia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%)
  • On ultrasound –
    • Double bubble sign
    • Polyhydramnios

 

 

Double bubble sign


Duodenal atresia is a congenital defect in which there is a closure or absence of a portion of the lumen of the duodenum. It can be diagnosed prenatally during a routine level 2 scan at around 20 weeks of gestation. Let's look at each option:

 

Option A. Associated Cardiac Anomalies: Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with other anomalies, including cardiac anomalies. About 30% of infants with duodenal atresia also have congenital heart disease.

 

Option B. Double Bubble Sign: This sign refers to two distinct fluid-filled areas seen on ultrasound, representing the stomach and the proximal duodenum. It is a classic sign of duodenal atresia as the duodenum is distended due to the obstruction.

 

Option C. Macrosomia: This term refers to a newborn who is significantly larger than average, often defined as a birth weight of more than 4,000 to 4,500 grams. Macrosomia would not be a finding in the case of duodenal atresia, especially at 20 weeks, since it generally refers to the condition of a newborn at birth. Duodenal atresia may cause growth issues due to nutrient malabsorption, but it is not associated with an increased fetal size in utero.

 

Option D. Polyhydramnios: Since the fetus is unable to properly process and absorb amniotic fluid due to the atresia, this can lead to an accumulation of fluid in the amniotic sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On a prenatal ultrasound, the "double bubble" sign is indicative of duodenal atresia, and associated cardiac anomalies may also be present. Polyhydramnios can occur due to the fetus's inability to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid properly. Macrosomia, which describes a newborn with a significantly larger than average birth weight, is not related to duodenal atresia and would not be seen on the ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation

 

Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The abnormal adherence is due to partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
Microscopically, the placental villi are found attached to smooth muscle fibers
There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of Placenta accrete syndromes in the same pregnancy
About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

Explanation

  • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis
    • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
    • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
    • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
    • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

In Placenta Accrete Syndromes, the abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer

 

Ref: Page no 1974, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: All the following have been implicated in spontaneous abortion except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subclinical hyperthyroidism

 

Subclinical hyperthyroidism is not implicated in causing spontaneous abortion

 

The endocrine disorders implicated in causing spontaneous abortion are:

 

  1. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  2. Overt hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
  3. Subclinical hypothyroidism with antithyroid antibodies
  4. Luteal phase defect
  5. PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

The endocrine disorders implicated in causing spontaneous abortion are:

 

  1. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  2. Overt hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
  3. Subclinical hypothyroidism with antithyroid antibodies
  4. Luteal phase defect
  5. PCOS

 

Ref: Page no. 347, Williams 25th edition

choices.text: Conjoined twins at term
First twin breech presentation

questions.text: All are indications for elective LSCS in multiple pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic twins

 

Indications for Elective LSCS in Twin pregnancy: (These are apart from Obstetric indications)

 

  1. First twin – non cephalic
  2. Triplets and above
  3. Monoamniotic Monochorionic (at 34 weeks)
  4. Conjoined twins

 

Monochorionic twins as such is not at indication for Elective LSCS unless it is monochorionic monoamniotic

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Conjoined Twins at Term: Conjoined twins present unique challenges for delivery, making vaginal delivery practically impossible and risky. Cesarean section is typically the chosen mode of delivery.

 

Option B. First Twin Breech Presentation: Breech presentation of the first twin increases the risk of complications during vaginal delivery hence LSCS is preferred.

 

Option C. Monochorionic Twins (Correct Answer): Simply being monochorionic is not an automatic indication for elective LSCS. The decision for mode of delivery in monochorionic twins depends on other factors like fetal positions, gestational age,amnionicity  and the presence of any complications.

 

Option D. Triplet Pregnancy: Elective LSCS is often considered for triplet pregnancies due to the increased risks associated with vaginal delivery in such cases. The complexity and potential complications of delivering multiple babies increase with the number of fetuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indications for Elective LSCS in Twin pregnancy: (These are apart from Obstetric indications)

 

  1. First twin – non cephalic
  2. Triplets and above
  3. Monoamniotic Monochorionic (at 34 weeks)
  4. Conjoined twins

 

Ref: page no 890, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

questions.text: Uncomplicated triplet pregnancy should be delivered at
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 35 weeks

 

  • After 36 weeks, the complications in triplet pregnancy increases
  • As per NICE guidelines, uncomplicated triplet pregnancy should be delivered by 35 weeks gestation

 

At this gestational age, the risks associated with prematurity are significantly lower than at earlier weeks, but the risks of prolonging the pregnancy are also mitigated.

 

Educational Objective: In summary, for uncomplicated triplet pregnancies, the recommended time for delivery is around 35 weeks to balance the risks associated with prematurity and potential complications of a prolonged pregnancy.

 

Ref: Evidence review for timing of birth in twin and triplet pregnancy; NICE guidelines No 137

questions.text: As per the WHO, abortion is defined as pregnancy loss or termination before:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20 weeks

 

  • The WHO and the CDC define abortion as pregnancy loss or termination before 20 weeks or with a fetus < 500g

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition; page no 346

choices.text: Repeat amniocentesis after 1 week

questions.text: At 28 weeks gestation amniocentesis reveals  OD 450 in Liley's zone 3. Which of the following is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intrauterine transfusion

 

  • Management of an already sensitized pregnancy (i.e., ICT positive)
    • Check ICT monthly till 24 weeks and weekly thereafter till critical titers are reached.
    • Critical titer is > 1: 16
    • Once critical titer is reached - Check Peak systolic velocity of Middle cerebral artery (PSV of MCA)
    • If PSV of MCA > 1.5 MoM – Cordocentesis and check fetal Hematocrit (Hct)
    • If Hct of fetal blood is < 30% - Intra uterine transfusion with O negative blood is transfused
    • Earlier, amniotic fluid spectrophotometry was done to determine the level of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid (indirectly assessing anemia) by spectrophotometry (bilirubin peaks at a wavelength of 450 nm). This value is then plotted on Liley’s graph. (> 27 weeks) or Queenans graph (< 27 weeks)
      • Zone 1 & lower level of zone 2: Repeat Amniocentesis after 2 weeks
      • Upper zone 2: Cordocentesis and Intra-uterine transfusion if Hct < 30%
      • Zone 3: cordocentesis and Intra-uterine transfusion

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Immediate delivery: Delivering the baby at 28 weeks poses significant risks due to prematurity. Immediate delivery is typically considered when the fetus is at a viable gestational age and if intrauterine interventions are not possible or have failed.

 

Option B. Intrauterine transfusion (Correct Answer): A Δ OD 450 in Liley's zone 3 indicates severe fetal anemia. Intrauterine transfusion is the preferred treatment for severe fetal anemia, especially at a gestational age where the fetus is not yet viable for delivery. This procedure involves transfusing blood directly to the fetus and can significantly improve fetal condition.

 

Option C. Repeat amniocentesis after 1 week: Given that Liley's zone 3 represents severe fetal anemia, waiting another week without intervention could lead to worsening of the fetal condition.

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis: Plasmapheresis is a procedure used to remove antibodies from the mother's blood. While it can be used in cases of immune-mediated diseases, it is not the first-line treatment for fetal anemia indicated by Liley's zone 3 findings. The efficacy of plasmapheresis in changing pregnancy outcomes in Rh isoimmunization is not conclusively established. Its use is limited to certain cases where the potential benefits outweigh the risks and complexities of the procedure.

 

Educational Objective: In cases where amniocentesis reveals Δ OD 450 in Liley's zone 3, indicating severe fetal anemia, the best line of management is intrauterine transfusion. This intervention directly addresses the fetal anemia, providing immediate treatment to improve fetal health and outcome.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition
